A1.T1.caption: Table 1: Categorical features cardinalities.
A1.T1.table:
feature cat0 cat1 cat2 cat3 cat4 cat5 cat6 cat7 cat8 cat9 cat10 cat11 cat12
cardinality 9 9 1025 98 122 1296 2492 3183 3541 2879 2314 1436 912
references: Table 1, 2 and 3 demonstrate the available statistics for categorical features cardinalities, index features and binary features respectively. Additionally, we provide statistics for selection bias of the job campaign that comes from the Criteo AdTech company (outside of FairJob dataset) in Table 4, which we take into account further to compute utility metrics.

A1.T2.caption: Table 2: Statistics for index features.
A1.T2.table:
feature user_id impression_id product_id
cardinality 30361 224898 57355
references: Table 1, 2 and 3 demonstrate the available statistics for categorical features cardinalities, index features and binary features respectively. Additionally, we provide statistics for selection bias of the job campaign that comes from the Criteo AdTech company (outside of FairJob dataset) in Table 4, which we take into account further to compute utility metrics.

A1.T3.caption: Table 3: Statistics for binary features (out of 1072226 rows).
A1.T3.table:
feature protected_attribute senior displayrandom click
positive 536113 (50%) 713659 (66.6%) 105869 (9.9%) 7489 (0.7%)
references: Table 1, 2 and 3 demonstrate the available statistics for categorical features cardinalities, index features and binary features respectively. Additionally, we provide statistics for selection bias of the job campaign that comes from the Criteo AdTech company (outside of FairJob dataset) in Table 4, which we take into account further to compute utility metrics.

A1.T4.caption: Table 4: Statistics for job campaign selection bias: we see that while female (internet)-population is slightly larger than male, the female population in the job campaign is much smaller, leading to selection bias of the job campaign – male users are almost twice more picked than female users.
A1.T4.table:
population advertising job campaign ratio
female 53.6% 39.2% 0.73
male 46.4% 60.7% 1.31
references: Table 1, 2 and 3 demonstrate the available statistics for categorical features cardinalities, index features and binary features respectively. Additionally, we provide statistics for selection bias of the job campaign that comes from the Criteo AdTech company (outside of FairJob dataset) in Table 4, which we take into account further to compute utility metrics.

A1.T5.caption: Table 5: Observed frequencies for clicks, senior job ads, and protected attribute
A1.T5.table:
not clicked clicked
non-senior senior non-senior senior all
female 189982 342221 1274 2636 536113
male 166394 366140 917 2662 536113
all 356376 708361 2191 5298 1072226
references:
We provide the detailed statistics on clicks, job seniority and the protected attribute in the dataset in Table 5. From this table we can compute probabilities of events. For example, Table 6 shows that if a job ad is about a senior position, there is slightly higher chance that it will be shown to a male user than female (by 3.36%), while an assistant job ad is more likely to be shown to a female user than male (by 6.68%).
In contrast, as can be seen in Table 7, there is almost no difference in clicks for senior ads given the protected attribute (both 0.49%) and a job add is slightly more likely to be clicked if shown to a female user (by 0.06%).

A1.T6.caption: Table 6: Observed frenquencies for user’s protected attribute given the seniority of the shown job ad.
A1.T6.table:
non-senior senior
female 0.533390 0.483224
male 0.466610 0.516776
references:
We provide the detailed statistics on clicks, job seniority and the protected attribute in the dataset in Table 5. From this table we can compute probabilities of events. For example, Table 6 shows that if a job ad is about a senior position, there is slightly higher chance that it will be shown to a male user than female (by 3.36%), while an assistant job ad is more likely to be shown to a female user than male (by 6.68%).
In contrast, as can be seen in Table 7, there is almost no difference in clicks for senior ads given the protected attribute (both 0.49%) and a job add is slightly more likely to be clicked if shown to a female user (by 0.06%).

A1.T7.caption: Table 7: Observed joint frenquencies for clicks, senior job ads, conditional on the protected attribute.
A1.T7.table:
not clicked clicked
non-senior senior non-senior senior
female 0.354369 0.638337 0.002376 0.004917
male 0.310371 0.682953 0.001710 0.004965
references:
We provide the detailed statistics on clicks, job seniority and the protected attribute in the dataset in Table 5. From this table we can compute probabilities of events. For example, Table 6 shows that if a job ad is about a senior position, there is slightly higher chance that it will be shown to a male user than female (by 3.36%), while an assistant job ad is more likely to be shown to a female user than male (by 6.68%).
In contrast, as can be seen in Table 7, there is almost no difference in clicks for senior ads given the protected attribute (both 0.49%) and a job add is slightly more likely to be clicked if shown to a female user (by 0.06%).

A2.T8.caption: Table 8: Performance comparison for single simulation of Dummy classifier (unaware) and XGBoost (unaware and unfair) with 100 trials for tuning.
A2.T8.table:
NLLH ↓↓\downarrow↓ AUC ↑↑\uparrow↑ DP ↓↓\downarrow↓ U𝑈Uitalic_U ↑↑\uparrow↑ U~~𝑈\tilde{U}over~ start_ARG italic_U end_ARG ↑↑\uparrow↑
Dummy unaware 0.69239 0.50000 0.00000 0.01009 0.01245
XGB unaware 0.05491 0.75787 0.00278 0.01017 0.01276
XGB unfair 0.05736 0.76201 0.00323 0.01037 0.01236
references: Figure 7 represents the feature importance according to an importance gain of XGBoost trained in two different ways: (i) unaware without protected attribute as a feature and (ii) unfair way with protected attribute as a feature. Their performance is reported in Table 8. We notice that the feature rank has a high importance, however, it gets replaced by the protected_attribute feature in the unfair regime. There most impactful features for both models are num23, num33, num43, num18 and num19, apart from rank for the unaware model and protected_attribute for the unfair one.

We train (i) a Dummy in the unaware regime to obtain the first baseline and (ii) XGB in two regimes (unaware and unfair) to achieve a more reasonable baseline performance, see Table 8. We notice that the Dummy classifier is perfectly fair with respect to DP which is reasonable since it did not learn at all as can be seen from the NLLH results.
